stem: A fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus is most likely to injure which nerve?
explanation: The axillary nerve winds around the surgical neck with the posterior circumflex humeral artery.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Wrist drop following a humeral shaft fracture indicates injury to which structure?
explanation: The radial nerve in the radial (spiral) groove is vulnerable in mid‑shaft fractures, leading to wrist/finger extensor weakness.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after a fall on the outstretched hand points to which fracture?
explanation: Scaphoid fracture classically presents with snuffbox tenderness; retrograde blood supply risks avascular necrosis.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which muscle initiates the first 15° of shoulder abduction?
explanation: Supraspinatus (suprascapular nerve) initiates abduction; deltoid (axillary) continues beyond ~15°.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Damage to which nerve causes loss of thumb opposition (ape hand)?
explanation: The recurrent motor branch of the median nerve supplies thenar muscles responsible for opposition.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The deep palmar arch is primarily formed by which artery?
explanation: Deep palmar arch: mainly radial with ulnar contribution; superficial arch is mainly ulnar.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Injury to the ulnar nerve at the elbow most prominently weakens which movement?
explanation: Ulnar nerve innervates interossei for finger ab/adduction; injury causes weak abduction/adduction.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The most commonly dislocated carpal bone is:
explanation: Lunate is most commonly dislocated; scaphoid is most commonly fractured.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Foot drop following fibular neck injury is due to damage of:
explanation: The common peroneal winds around the fibular neck and supplies dorsiflexors via deep peroneal branch.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: A femoral nerve block is most accurately placed at which landmark?
options: Mid‑inguinal point lateral to femoral artery
Medial to femoral vein at inguinal ligament
Halfway between ASIS and pubic tubercle
explanation: Femoral nerve lies lateral to femoral artery under the inguinal ligament at the mid‑inguinal point.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The dorsalis pedis artery is a continuation of which vessel?
explanation: Anterior tibial becomes dorsalis pedis distal to the ankle joint.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which ligament most resists anterior translation of the tibia on the femur?
explanation: ACL prevents anterior tibial translation and resists rotational forces.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which muscle is primarily responsible for hip abduction during gait (Trendelenburg sign when weak)?
explanation: Gluteus medius (and minimus) stabilize pelvis during stance; superior gluteal nerve.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Sensory loss in the first web space indicates lesion of which nerve?
explanation: Deep peroneal nerve supplies the first dorsal web space.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: A fracture of the neck of the talus risks avascular necrosis due to disruption of which vessel pattern?
options: Retrograde blood supply to the body
Artery to the sinus tarsi only
explanation: The talar body has retrograde intraosseous flow; neck fractures compromise body perfusion.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: At which vertebral level does the trachea bifurcate in adults at end‑expiration?
explanation: The carina lies at the sternal angle corresponding to the T4–T5 intervertebral level.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which coronary artery most commonly supplies the AV node (right‑dominant circulation)?
explanation: In ~85% (right dominance) the AV nodal artery arises from the RCA at the crux.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The right main bronchus is more prone to aspiration because it is:
explanation: Right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertical.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Pain from the foregut is typically referred to which region?
explanation: Foregut visceral pain localizes to the epigastrium; midgut to umbilical; hindgut to suprapubic.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The portal triad within the hepatoduodenal ligament contains:
options: Hepatic vein, portal vein, bile duct
Portal vein, proper hepatic artery, common bile duct
Cystic artery, portal vein, bile duct
Proper hepatic artery, cystic duct, hepatic vein
explanation: From posterior to anterior: portal vein posterior, proper hepatic artery anteromedial, common bile duct anterolateral (variations exist).

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: McBurney’s point overlies which structure in typical anatomy?
options: Appendix base at convergence of taeniae
explanation: The base of the appendix lies at the confluence of taeniae coli near McBurney’s point.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which artery is the primary source for the superior epigastric artery?
explanation: Superior epigastric is a terminal branch of the internal thoracic artery.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Loss of the corneal blink reflex (efferent limb) indicates dysfunction of which nerve?
explanation: Afferent is ophthalmic (V1); efferent is facial (VII) to orbicularis oculi.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which ossicle articulates with the oval window of the vestibule?
explanation: The footplate of the stapes occupies the oval window, transmitting vibrations to the inner ear.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Loss of pain and temperature contralateral to a lateral medullary lesion reflects damage to:
explanation: The anterolateral (spinothalamic) pathway crosses early and ascends contralaterally.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: An epidural hematoma typically arises from laceration of which vessel?
explanation: Temporal bone fractures may tear the middle meningeal artery → biconvex extra‑dural bleed.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve causes weakness of:
explanation: The marginal mandibular branch supplies muscles depressing the lower lip.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: A lesion of the right oculomotor nerve would most likely cause which finding?
options: Ptosis and dilated pupil on right
explanation: CN III palsy → ptosis (levator), ‘down and out’ eye, and mydriasis (parasympathetic).

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The pudendal nerve exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen and re‑enters via the lesser sciatic foramen to reach:
explanation: Pudendal nerve enters Alcock’s canal on the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which structure forms the anterior boundary of the perineal membrane’s urogenital hiatus?
explanation: The urogenital hiatus opens anteriorly beneath the pubic arch; perineal body is posterior midline tendon.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Rupture of the spongy urethra with Buck’s fascia torn allows urine to spread to:
explanation: Urine can track into the superficial perineal space and up the lower anterior abdominal wall deep to Scarpa’s fascia.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Compression of the L5 nerve root typically produces weakness of which movement?
explanation: L5 root innervates dorsiflexors (deep peroneal); patients struggle with heel walking.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Which ligament prevents hyperflexion of the vertebral column?
explanation: Interspinous and supraspinous ligaments resist flexion; ALL resists extension.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The conus medullaris typically ends at which vertebral level in adults?
explanation: Adult spinal cord ends around L1–L2; cauda equina continues below.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: A Meckel’s diverticulum is a remnant of which embryologic structure?
explanation: Meckel’s diverticulum results from persistence of the vitelline duct on the antimesenteric ileum.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The safe triangle for chest drain insertion is bounded by the latissimus dorsi, pectoralis major, a line superior to the nipple level, and:
explanation: Safe triangle: anterior to latissimus, lateral to pec major, above level of nipple (5th ICS), apex at axilla.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: During cricothyrotomy, the membrane pierced is between which cartilages?
explanation: Cricothyroid membrane spans between thyroid cartilage and cricoid arch.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: A chest tube placed too inferiorly at the mid‑axillary line risks penetrating which organ on the right?
explanation: Low placement below 5th ICS may injure the liver on the right (or spleen on the left).

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: The foramen ovale transmits which structure?
explanation: Foramen ovale: V3; rotundum: V2; spinosum: middle meningeal artery; lacerum: cartilage/ICA over.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Loss of vibration and proprioception on the right below T6 suggests a lesion of which tract?
explanation: Dorsal column modalities ascend ipsilaterally; gracile tract carries lower limb proprioception.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Carotid sinus baroreceptors are innervated primarily by:
explanation: Carotid sinus via Hering’s nerve (IX); aortic arch via vagus (X).

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: An indirect inguinal hernia passes:
options: Medial to inferior epigastric vessels via Hesselbach’s triangle
Lateral to inferior epigastric vessels via deep ring
Through femoral canal medial to lacunar ligament
Directly through transversalis fascia above arcuate line
explanation: Indirect hernia enters deep inguinal ring lateral to inferior epigastrics and may traverse the canal.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Pain and swelling over the tibial tuberosity in an adolescent athlete most likely indicates:
explanation: Osgood–Schlatter: traction apophysitis of tibial tuberosity from repetitive quadriceps pull.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy

stem: Cubital tunnel syndrome results from compression of which nerve at the elbow?
explanation: Ulnar nerve compression in the cubital tunnel causes paresthesia in ulnar digits and intrinsic weakness.

sources.title: Clinically Oriented Anatomy (Moore & Dalley)
Abrahams & McMinn’s Clinical Atlas of Human Anatomy
